variant.question:
An aircraft is departing from Lille, call sign D-ENRW, runways in use 26 and 20. The pilot receives the following message: “D-RW, behind the landing Airbus, line up and wait runway 26 behind”

options.text: The message was preceded by: “D-RW, report Airbus on final in sight” with a reply from the pilot “D-RW, Airbus in sight.” Following the message given by the question text, the pilot will read back: “Behind Airbus, lining up and waiting runway 26 behind, D-RW”.

The message was preceded by. “D-RW ready for immediate departure”. Following the message given by the question text, the pilot will read back: “Behind Airbus, lining up and waiting runway 26 behind, D-RW”.
Following the message given by the question text, the pilot will read back: “Behind Airbus, lining up and waiting, D-RW”.

The message was preceded by: “D-RW, report Airbus on final in sight” with a reply from the pilot “D-RW, Airbus in sight”. Following the message given by the question text, the pilot will read back: “Behind Airbus, lining up and waiting, D-RW”.

The change in callsign can be made anytime thought convenient and has to be announced to ATC using the phrase “Skyfall four seven changing callsign to Golf Alpha Charlie Zulu Golf.”

variant.question: Your flight plan has been filed with the call sign GOLF ALFA CHARLIE ZULU GOLF. At 15:15, Air Traffic Control instructed you to "CHANGE YOUR CALL SIGN TO SKYFALL ZULU GOLF" with no additional information. When should you change back to using GOLF ALFA CHARLIE ZULU GOLF?

options.text: Only when instructed to "REVERT TO FLIGHT PLAN CALLSIGN GOLF ALFA CHARLIE ZULU GOLF".
Automatically on passing the next reporting point, or when instructed by ATC to do so.
When instructed by ATC to do so, or automatically at 15:45.
Automatically on making the next frequency change, or when instructed by ATC to do so.

variant.question: You receive the following message from ATC: “BIGJET 345 change yor callsign to G-ABCD.” What would be the reason for this message.

options.text: In the interests of safety to avoid confusion with aircraft with similar callsigns.
You requested the change and ATC have approved it.
You have been instructed to change by your company.
This request would never be made as you cannot change your flight plan callsign.

variant.question: You are using the callsign 'ABC 312', and another aircraft comes on frequency with the callsign 'Echo 312'. What action may the controller take?

options.text: You may be instructed to change the type of callsign temporarily.
No action is required as the first part of each callsign is different.
You may be asked to make up a new callsign.
Both aircraft must start to use their registrations as their callsigns.

The ICAO Phonetic alphabet is used to spell out words:

options.text: When the crew is unsure of the correct pronunciation and to avoid lack of intelligibility.
Always when cleared to a navaid or waypoint.
Always when cleared to a VOR.
Always when reading aircraft registration or cleared to a waypoint or navaid.

variant.question: You are operating a flight for which a flight plan has been filed with the callsign Golf Alpha Charlie Zulu Golf. At 15:15 UTC, you are instructed by ATC to “Change your callsign to Skyfall Zulu Golf” without any additional information. When should you change back to your original callsign of Golf Alpha Charlie Zulu Golf?

options.text: Only when instructed by ATC using the phrase “Revert to flight plan callsign Golf Alpha Charlie Zulu Golf”.
When instructed by ATC, or automatically at 15:45 UTC.
Automatically when you pass the next reporting point, or when instructed by ATC.
Automatically when communication is transferred to the next frequency, or when instructed by ATC.

Your aircraft registration is G-ZBKN.
Your flight number is BA 0093.

There are three ways that an aircraft call sign can be transmitted on initial contact.
1. The characters corresponding to the registration marking of the aircraft.
2. The telephony designator of the aircraft operating agency, followed by the last four characters of the registration marking of the aircraft and:

options.text: The telephony designator of the aircraft operating agency followed by the flight identification.
Aircraft model plus full aircraft registration
Aircraft manufacturer plus abbreviated aircraft registration.
The telephony designator of the aircraft operating agency followed by the last two letters of the aircraft registration.

variant.question: On the current frequency in use there are two different callsigns ABC 123 and DCB 123. What could you expect to happen?

options.text: You may be instructed by the tower to change to a new callsign.
You take the initiative to change to new callsign.
May be ask to come up with a new callsign.
May be forced to leave the frequency.

variant.question: What does the phrase "BREAK BREAK" mean?

options.text: It indicates the separation between messages transmitted to different aircraft in a very busy environment.
The exchange of transmissions has ended and no response is expected.
It indicates the separation between portions of a message transmitted to an aircraft station.
My transmission has ended and I expect a response from you.

variant.question: Which statement is correct regarding the use of “heavy” and “super” in context with callsigns?

options.text: “Heavy” is used as a suffix to the callsign of aircraft belonging to the wake turbulence category “H”.
“Super” is used as a prefix in the callsign of an Airbus A380 only.
“Heavy” is used as a prefix to the callsign of aircraft belonging to the wake turbulence category “J”.
“Super” is used as a suffix in the callsign of an Airbus A340 or A380.

variant.question: On the same frequency, two aircraft are having the following respective call-signs: ABC123 and DCB123. What instruction can you expect from the ATC?

options.text: Be advised of call sign similarity and look out for traffic.
Fly heading North and repeat your call sign.

variant.question: MSAW stands for...

A light aircraft with call sign F-EAVX is flying outside of Lille approach's radio range. Lille approach requests another aircraft with call sign Fastair 144 to relay the change of communications to Paris control on 128.10. Which of the following transmissions from Fastair 144 is correct?

options.text: Fastair 144, relaying Lille Approach for F-EAVX , call Paris control 128.10.
Fastair 144, relaying Lille approach for F-EAVX , contact Paris control 128.10.

variant.question: Your flight is "British Airways 0049", the aircraft registration number is GE-ABT. You would like to change your call sign to one containing "Speedbird". Which one of the following call signs may be used?

You receive the following instruction from ATC:
HOTAIR ALPHA GOLF, RESET SQUAWK CHARLIE **3363**
What are you going to do?

options.text: Reselect code 3363, ensure pressure altitdue is being transmitted and reply: "RESETTING CHARLIE 3 363, HOTAIR ALPHA GOLF"
Reselect code 3363 and reply: "WILCO, HOTAIR ALPHA GOLF"
Check that 3363 is shown on your transponder, select IDENT, then reply: "RESETTING CHARLIE 3 363, HOTAIR ALPHA GOLF"
Check that 3363 is shown on your transponder and if altitude is also selected, then reply: "SQUAWKING CHARLIE 3 363, HOTAIR ALPHA GOLF"

variant.question: Under which circumstance will you most likely change your heading?

options.text: Traffic at your twelve o'clock, same level and opposite direction.
Traffic at your six o'clock, same level behind you.
Traffic at your twelve o'clock, 500 feet below and opposite direction.
Traffic at your six o'clock, 500 feet above you and opposite direction.

the characters corresponding to the registration marking of the aircraft.
the telephony designator of the aircraft operating agency, followed by the flight identification.

variant.question: What does the phrase "SQUAWK **1234**" mean?

Make a test transmission on 123.4 MHz.
Give a short count for DF (direction finder).

variant.question: The condition that defines the state of an aircraft in imminent danger is referred to as:
